facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2034 of 1969 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2034 of 1969. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 7, 1969 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in Civil Writ No. 850 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 7, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Civil Writ No. 850 of 1969.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the writ petition. It appears that several contentions were sought

facts.text: Appellants challenged validity of proceedings under ss. 4, 6, 9 and 17(2)(c) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 as amended by Punjab Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: writ petition wherein the appellants challenged the validity of proceedings under ss. 4, 6, 9 and 17  2   c  of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 as amended by the Punjab Legislature.

facts.text: Government of Haryana issued notification under s.4 on 14/17 March 1969 notifying acquisition of land for setting up factory for manufacture of China-ware and Porcelain ware including Wall Glazed Tiles at village Kasser Tehsil Jhajjar District Rohtak.

anchor.surface_text: On 14/17 March, 1969, Government of Haryana issued a notification under s. 4 of the Act notifying for acquisition the land concerned in this case. The notification further directed that action under s. 17  2   c  of the Act shall be taken on the ground of urgency and the provisions of s. 5-A shall not apply in regard to the said acquisition. The preamble to the said notification says that whereas it appears to the Governor of Haryana that land is likely to be required to be taken by Government, at public expenses, for a public purpose, namely for the setting up a factory for the manufacture of Chine-ware and Porcelain ware including Wall Glazed Tiles etc. at village Kasser Tehsil Jhajjar, District Rohtak, it is here by notified that the land in the locality described in the specification below is likely to be required for the above purpose.

facts.text: Notification under s.4 directed action under s.17(2)(c) on ground of urgency and provisions of s.5A shall not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The notification further directed that action under s. 17  2   c  of the Act shall be taken on the ground of urgency and the provisions of s. 5-A shall not apply in regard to the said acquisition.

facts.text: Government issued notification under s.6 on March 18, 1969 acquiring the land for public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1969 the Government issued a notification under s. 6 of the Act acquiring the land for a public purpose-

facts.text: Notices under s.9 served on appellants on March 28, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On March 28, 1969 notices under s. 9 of the Act were served on the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition on April 8, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On April 8, 1969, the appellants filed the writ petition giving rise to this appeal.

facts.text: Petitioners alleged no urgency justifying recourse to s.17 and deprivation of s.5A.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations in the writ petition include the assertion that there was no urgency in the matter of acquiring the land in question and therefore there was no justification for having recourse to s. 17 and thus deprive the appellants of the benefit of, s. 5-A of- the Act.

facts.text: Petitioners alleged acquisition for benefit of a company, should have been under ss.38-44B.

anchor.surface_text: It was further alleged therein that the acquisition in question was made for the benefit of a company and hence proceedings should have been taken under ss. 38 to 44 B  of the Act and that there was no public purpose involved in the case.

facts.text: Petitioners alleged land was not waste or arable land and s.17(2)(c) did not confer power to dispense with s.5A.

anchor.surface_text: It was further pleaded that the land acquired was no waste and arable land and that s.  2  c  of the Act did no confer power on the Government to dispense with the proceedings under s. 5-A.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit by Deputy Director of Industries Administration, Government of Haryana denied all above allegations.

anchor.surface_text: In the counter-affidavit filed by the Deputy Director of Industries  Administration , Government of Haryana On behalf of the State of Haryana, the above allegations were all denied.

facts.text: Government of India issued letter of intent to a company for setting up factory for Glazed Tiles etc. in village Kasser at instance of State of Haryana.

anchor.surface_text: Therein it is stated that at the instance of the State of Haryana, Government of India had issued a letter of intent to a company for setting up a factory for the manufacture of Glazed Tiles etc. in village Kasser.

facts.text: Project to be started with collaboration of foreign company Pilkington Tiles Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: That project was to be started with the collaboration of a foreign company, known as Pilkington Tiles Ltd.

facts.text: Scheme for setting up project finalised and approved by concerned authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme for setting up the project had been finalised and approved by the concerned authorities.

facts.text: On November 26, 1968, Government wrote to Shri H.L. Somany, one of promoters, to complete arrangements for import of capital equipment and acquisition of land, extended time for completing project upto April 30, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: on November 26, 1968, the Government wrote to one of the pro- moters of the project, Shri H. L. Somany asking him to com- plete the arrangements for the import of capital equipment and acquisition of land in Haryana State-- for setting up of the proPosed factory. It was further stated in that communication the Government was pleased to extend the time for compeing the Project upto April 30, 1969.

facts.text: State of Haryana lacking in industries, difficult to tackle unemployment problem.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated in the affidavit filed on behalf of the State Government that the  State of Haryana was lacking in industries and consequently it was become difficult to tackle the problem of unemployment.

facts.text: State Government contributed Rs. 100/- towards cost of land as mentioned in award of Land Acquisition Officer.

anchor.surface_text: We were informed at the bar that the State Government had contributed  1  1963 2 S.C.R. 774.  2  1967 1 S.C.R. 373. a sum of Rs. 100/- towards the cost of the land which fact is also mentioned in the award of Land Acquisition Officer.

facts.text: Court found acquisition at public expense for public purpose of setting up industry.

anchor.surface_text: There is no denying the fact that starting of a new industry is in public interest. ... On the facts of this case there can be hardly any doubt that the purpose for which the land was acquired is a public purpose.

facts.text: Court found there was urgency as project completion time extended to April 30, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Now coming to the question of urgency, it is clear from the facts set out earlier that there was urgency, The Government of India was pleased to extend time for the completion of the of project upto April 30, 1969.

facts.text: Appellant denied entire land is waste or arable; contention not examined by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had denied in the affidavit that the entire land acquired is either waste or arable Iand That contention of his has no been examined by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As none of the contentions taken by the appellants are ac- ceptable, thise appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: No order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: But in the circumstances of the case we make no order as to costs.

arguments.claim: Purpose is public purpose per declaration; conclusive under s.6(3) unless colourable exercise.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 3  says that the declaration of the Government that the acquisition made is for public purpose shall be conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a public purpose. ... arguments.claim: Acquisition at public expense (State contributed Rs.100), so not under Part VII.

anchor.surface_text: We were informed at the bar that the State Government had contributed  1  1963 2 S.C.R. 774.  2  1967 1 S.C.R. 373. a sum of Rs. 100/- towards the companyt of the land which fact is also mentioned in the award of Land Acquisition Officer. That being so it was number necessary for the Government to proceed with the acquisition under Part VII of the Act-see Somavantis case 1 .

arguments.claim: s.17(2)(c) has plain wide scope; ejusdem generis inapplicable as cls.(a),(b) lack common genus.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 2  c  if read by itself is plain. It seems to permit the appropriate Government to direct that the provisions of Section 5-A shall number apply whenever land is required for public purpose which in the opinion of the appropriate Government is of urgent importance. ... Hence we are unable to accept the companytention that in interpreting cl.  c  of s. 17 2 , we should apply the rule of ejusdem generis.

holdings.text: The purpose for which the land was acquired is a public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case there can be hardly any doubt that the purpose for which the land was acquired is a public purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Starting new industry in industrially backward Haryana aids public interest and combats unemployment; s.6(3) declaration conclusive absent colorable exercise; follows Somavanti.

holdings.text: Acquisition not required to proceed under Part VII (ss.38-44B) as made at public expense.

anchor.surface_text: We were informed at the bar that the State Government had contributed a sum of Rs. 100/- towards the cost of the land which fact is also mentioned in the award of Land Acquisition Officer. That being so it was not necessary for the Government to proceed with the acquisition under Part VII of the Act-see Somavantis case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State contributed Rs.100 to cost; acquisition at public expense even if benefiting company; follows Somavanti.

holdings.text: There was urgency justifying recourse to s.17.

anchor.surface_text: Now coming to the question of urgency, it is clear from the facts set out earlier that there was urgency, The Government of India was pleased to extend time for the completion of the of project upto April 30, 1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Project completion extended to April 30, 1969; required immediate land acquisition; Government's opinion on urgency entitled to weight.

holdings.text: s.17(2)(c) applies to facts; provisions of s.5A correctly dispensed with.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 as amended by the Punjab Act 2 of 1954... Whenever land is required for a public purpose which in the opinion of the appropriate Government is of urgent importance...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain text permits dispensation of s.5A for any urgent public purpose; assumes not waste/arable so not s.17(1); conditions met: public purpose and government opinion of urgency.

holdings.text: Ejusdem generis rule does not apply to interpret s.17(2)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Hence we are unable to accept the contention that in interpreting cl. c of s. 17 2 , we should apply the rule of ejusdem generis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses (a) and (b) lack distinct genus/category; different authorities and conditions; cites Halsbury, Craies, Sutherland, SC cases like Ali Gulshan, Lilavati Bai.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan 1

anchor.surface_text: In State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan 1  it was observed Apart from the fact that the rule must be companyfined within narrow limits, and general or companyprehensive words should recive their full and natural meaning unless they are clearly restrictive in their intendment, it is requisite that there must be a distinct genus, which must companyprise more than one species, before the rule can be applied In Lilavati Bai v.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan
precedents.cited_proposition: ejusdem generis rule must be confined within narrow limits and requires a distinct genus comprising more than one species
precedents.cited_holding: Apart from the fact that the rule must be confined within narrow limits... there must be a distinct genus, which must comprise more than one species, before the rule can be applied

precedents.citation: Lilavati Bai v. The State of Bombay, 2

anchor.surface_text: In Lilavati Bai v. The State of Bombay, 2  it was observed The rule of ejusdem generis is intended to be applied where general words have been used following particular and specific words of the same nature on the established rule of companystruction that the legislature presumed to use the general words in a restricted sense, that is to say, as belonging to the same genus as the particular and specific words.

precedents.case_name: Lilavati Bai v. The State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: ejusdem generis applies where context requires restricted meaning to general words following specific words of same genus
precedents.cited_holding: The rule of ejusdem generis is intended to be applied where general words have been used following particular and specific words of the same nature... Such a restricted meaning has to be given to words of general import only where the context of the whole scheme of legislation requires it.

precedents.citation: K. K. Kochini State of Madras and Kerala 1

anchor.surface_text: The same view was reiterated by this Court in K. K. Kochini State of Madras and Kerala 1 . Bearing in mind the principles set out earlier, we shall number companysider whether the general import of the words, in s. 17  2   e  should be cut down in view of s. 17  2   a  and  b . Under cl.  a  of s. 17 2 , the acquisition is to be made by the Railway Administration when owing to any sudden change in the, channel of any navigable river or other unforeseen emergency it becomes necessary for the administration to acquire the immediate possession of any land for the maintenance of the traffic or for the purpose of making thereon a river-side or ghat station or for providing companyvenient companynection with or access to any such station.

precedents.case_name: K. K. Kochini v. State of Madras and Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: reiterates the view on ejusdem generis rule as in previous cases
